fields.description:
If there is a team with many persons having a similar set of skills and an issue with a high number of estimated sub-tasks and many persons are allowed to work on a story's stages, there might be an OutOfMemoryError when calculating a schedule.

Suggested workarounds:
* split up or temporarily remove the large team or
* set the number of people who can work on a story stage to 2 or even 1 in Configure/Scheduling - Maximum assignees per story

h3. Additional information

(!) After upgrading to Portfolio 2.1.4+, you need to re-calculate the plan to update data in the database.
fields.summary: Calculation runs out of memory for large teams and issues with many subtasks

Hello,
While implementing Live Plan, you took the assumption that all your users want to commit scenarios to JIRA; this is not the case :(
Indeed, my Portfolio users (PMO and some scrum masters/POs) want to use Portfolio as sand box to generate bunch of scenarios. They want to undo changes and baseline scenarios and come back later to compare with other scenarios.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1473].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
If issues in Portfolio are sorted according to a column, and that column is later hidden/collapsed, the sort remains in effect. There is no visual indication of this, and as issues are sorted by a column, they cannot be reprioritised.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plan
# Add some issues.
# Drag to reprioritise.
# This will work. 
# Sort the issues by a column (e.g. click on the estimates column header to sort by estimates).
# Hide the estimates column.
# The issues remain sorted by the column, but there is no visual indication of this.
# Try to drag the issues to reprioritise.
# The issues cannot be moved.

h3. Expected Results
The sort should automatically be removed when the column is hidden/collapsed.

h3.Workaround
Expand/un-collapse columns until you find the one the issues are sorted by (the column header will have a grey background). Click on the column header to un-apply the sort. Re-hide the columns if desired. Issues are now displayed in priority order and can be drag-and-dropped to reprioritise.

Alternatively, the table can be sorted by the _Title_ column (which cannot be hidden) first and then sorting can be un-applied by clicking the title column two more times (first click changes sort direction, second takes the table back to their default sort order by rank which allows for rank operations).
fields.summary: Cannot reprioritize issues if they are sorted by a hidden column
show the ranking number in the first column

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1467].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently it is not possible to display epic priorities in Portfolio in the same way they are displayed in JIRA and vice versa. This is due to the fact that in JIRA all issues are ranked in a “flat” manner: you can have sub-tasks before parents and stories before epics, etc when you search for issues. In Portfolio, issues are displayed based on hierarchy and as such, they cannot be ranked in the same manner as those in JIRA.  
h3. Suggested Solution
Provide a way to import these priorities and hierarchies between Portfolio and JIRA, so that they can also be viewed in JIRA. 

h3. Workaround 
A possible workaround would be to change the order of your stories in JIRA based off how you would like your Epics ranked.
fields.summary: Mirror epic priorities between JIRA and Portfolio

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1464].
  {panel}

+Value Statement+: As a user, I want better sync from Software to Portfolio for uncommitted changes so I have accurate issue data.

With 2.0, the synchronization has improved tremendously between Software and Portfolio with Live Plans (now the standard plan).  But I am still having conflict problems with changes made to issues in Software and uncommitted changes to those same issues in Portfolio.

For instance (in this example we'll say the original release is _Version 1.0_ for the story):

# First, I'll change the Release for the story in Portfolio to _Version 2.0_. It will show as an Uncommitted change, as it should
# Next, I will go into that same story in Software and change the Release to _Version 2.5_. It updates there, so far so good
# Finally I go back into Portfolio, I have an uncommitted change that is different than my latest update to that same issue in Software.  There is no easy way to tell when looking through uncommitted changes what the effect would be
# If I revert the change in Portfolio, it will show the release as 2.5, the one I made in step 2
# If I commit the change in Portfolio, it will update the issue in Software as well to 2.0, the one I made in step 1

I don't know what the right solution would be.  Any change made in Software overrides any uncommitted changes in Portfolio?  A better view of uncommitted changes to know if there are conflicts between the two?
fields.summary: Better sync between Software and Portfolio for Uncommitted Changes

We have a Live Plan created that is tied to a single board as the source.

We are seeing that not all issues under the epics are showing up for import into Live Plans (as well as obviously seeing them in the imported scope).  The issue types are custom standard issue types.  The Portfolio admin screen shows that all standard issue types are mapped solely to the story level. Everything from that list checks out and we are just not sure that this isn't a bug of some sort.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The 3.x releases of pocket-knife included two methods - {{findTableNames}} and {{findColumnNames}} - which used a metadata query known to cause performance problems in Oracle: {{metaData.getTables(null, null, null, null)}} and {{metaData.getColumns(null, null, null, null)}}.

* http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2068665/oracle-10g-slow-metadata-queries
* https://community.oracle.com/thread/105008?start=0&tstart=0

This code has been removed on 4.x releases.

h3. Expected Behavior
Only retrieve metadata for objects relevant to the operation, which can be achieved by optimizing the call of this method - passing a new parameter to it that filters results.

Example: {{metaData.getTables(null, null, null, new String[]\{"TABLE"\})}}

In newer releases of pocket-knife, these two methods do not exist anymore. Since it was updated in Feb 2016, JPO should use this new release.

h3. Actual Behavior
This code ends up retrieving lots of objects from the public schema in Oracle that are not relevant. In one case, it returned 60,000 objects, causing a severe performance bottleneck in JIRA instances connected to this DBMS.

This library is used by JPO, and severely impacts the performance of JIRA in some actions when performed right after a restart. One of the actions impacted is adding comments to an issue, but also most of other issue updates.

The below can be seen when analyzing hot spots in database queries. Notice the query called by pocket-knife runs for ~35s.

!add_comment_jpo_pocketknife.png|thumbnail!

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Connect JIRA 7.1.x to an Oracle 12c database;
# Install JPO 1.x;
# Right after JIRA's startup, try creating a new project;
# Notice subsequent creation of projects will be considerably faster;

h3. Workaround
There are no known workarounds for this problem yet. However, the slowness is only noticed at the first time any issue update happens, until a restart of JIRA.
fields.summary: Update pocket-knife to 4.x

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1455].
  {panel}

I would like to plan, review capacity, and keep in sync with JIRA issues through portfolio in a way that does not cause headaches for the rest of the team.

What I would picture as a feature, would be the capability to assign a team to an epic/issue in Portfolio, but create a Portfolio configuration setting to leave an issue unassigned if the issue is currently unassigned.  The portfolio could still forecast capacities based on team member hours and skills.  

In the classic portfolio, I was able to accomplish this by creating a fake team member with the same number of hours available as the real team members combined.  I would then assign the "unassigned" user to all epics and stories that were still in the planning process.  I was effectively doubling my teams capacity in the eyes of Portfolio, so for the trick to work, I had to make sure to assign all issues manually to team members (real or unassigned) so I could maintain control over capacity.

I would like to have the ability to manage my capacities, while not yet being certain which developers would do the work.  My biggest headache is having portfolio assign team members to issues, having my updates and improvements on those issues slam their dashboards and emails, and knowing that the issue may not actually be assigned to them.
fields.summary: As a product manager, I want to be able to keep backlog issues unassigned while still taking in account my teams capacity, so that developers do not get confusing updates and emails
Provide an option to disable scheduling of issues without assignee

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1442].
  {panel}

*Problem statement*
In live plans, when the source (filter, board or project) returns resolved issues, these are not currently shown in the import preview.
They are nevertheless imported, and the user can display them by setting the _More->Completion date_ to a date sufficiently far back.

This behavior is confusing as the user has no perception that a bunch of issues are available but hidden in the plan. These issues are particularly relevant if the plan is used as a monitoring tool for a JIRA initiative that was started before the creation of the plan itself (and then will reasonably have a number of resolved issues at the time of import).

*Suggestion for the improvement*
I would recommend to modify the import preview to include the full list of the issues actually imported, regardless of whether they would then be hidden (for any kind of default display setting).
Optionally, the preview may notify the user that some of these issues will be hidden (ideally detailing which ones and why).

*Expected benefit*
This improvement would give the user a full understanding of what the plan will contain and will favor a better control of the different options and usage scenario
fields.summary: Import wizard in live plans should show that completed issues are imported

fields.description:
While importing issues on a Live plan, the plan *importer disregards a number of issues that the source should normally return*. 
The problem occurs using "board", as well as "filter" or "project" sources.

*I guess that "done" issues (=with a non-null resolution) are discarded*, since I cannot find any in the import preview of my plan ("Confirm what's in scope" page). This used to work just fine with standard plans.

I attach an example where my JIRA filter retrieves 229 items. When used as source of a live plan it only detects 113... where are the remaining 116?
  
  
*Why is this a problem*
I need to create plans for a JIRA initiative that is ongoing. This initiative will supposedly have a number of "completed" issues. If completed issues are not imported, the progress of epics would only take into account stories completed after the creation of my plan. That's clearly unacceptable: it should also count-in stories that were completed previously.

  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1438].
  {panel}

*Problem:*
You have a Live Plan and from there assign issues to a release that exists in JIRA, you do not commit this change but keep it pending. Next, you delete this version in JIRA. This will clean up all fix version assignments in JIRA but the pending fix version change in Portfolio is not affected by this operation.

Therefore, the issues are now exclusively assigned to a release that is not included in your plan - it has been deleted. Consequently, these issues are excluded from your plan (if issues are only assigned to releases that are not included in your plan, we exclude them). The still active scenario assignment has priority over JIRA assignments (otherwise you could never filter for changes active in the scenario etc.)

However, after refreshing your page, the pending changes for these issues disappear and they are just gone without a trace.

*Workaround*
At the moment, the best thing you can do is to create another plan based on the same issue sources and releases. However, any pending changes on the affected issues cannot be brought back to the new plan. 

We are working on a solution.
fields.summary: Issues that are scenario-assigned to a version that has been deleted in JIRA disappear from Live Plans

*Problem*
Once the replace existing option got turned on for a plan (keep existing is the default setting), it cannot be turned off. This affects all versions from 1.8.6 on.

*Workaround*
Go to the local storage of your browser and remove or manually modify the entry with the key _radiantminds.roadmap.plan-X.update-to-jira-options.sync-settings_. The _"replaceFixVersions"_ in the value must be set to _false_, e.g., {{"replaceFixVersions":false}} needs to be part of the value of this entry.

 !image-2016-05-17-17-08-26-448.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: "Fix version/s > Replace existing" option cannot be turned off in "Apply updates to projects" dialog

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1423].
  {panel}

Issue linking should persist and be visible when a custom hierarchy is in use. 

As an example: 

|- Feature
  |---- Epic
        |---- Story

Epic Link is used to create the relationship between the Story and Epic. We use "Issue Link" "parent" to establish the link/hierarchy between the Feature and Epic. On import in the Portfolio Live Plan, and after adding the Feature issue type to the hierarchy in Portfolio, the Epic/Story link is honored while the Feature/Epic link is not. 

At this point we manually linked all the Features/Epics in Portfolio, and committed the changes. There is no visible relationship added on the single JIRA issues outside of Portfolio. 

Ideally the linking is imported along with the issues, and is also updated/maintained when changed within Portfolio.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1417].
  {panel}

If I have one person on two projects (frequently...) and change the Schedule Settings to group by person, they are first grouped by project.

Project A
- Joe Bob <Issue>
- Betty Sue <Issue>

Project B
- Joe Bob <Issue>

Project C
- Betty Sue <Issue>

What I expected to be able to do was show something like the list below to visualize cross-project assignment and capacity issues.

Joe Bob
<Project A issue>
<Project B issue>

Betty Sue 
<Project A issue>
<Project C issue>
fields.summary: Grouping by Person displays "By Person By Project".
Hide epics in Portfolio timeline view

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1415].
  {panel}

	​As a Scrum Master/Release Manager/Product Owner/Project Coordinator/Tribe Leader, I want to display the User Stories in a drop menu under the Epic, in the Epic Report Display.
 in order to visualize dependencies, maximize the resources assignments and eventually adjust the scope & priorities of my backlog.

*Dod : *	
The Epic report shows the possibility to display, with a drop menu, all user stories inside the Epic Report display (see attachment)
fields.summary: Aggregate epic and story data in a single view (expand epics in visual timeline)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1414].
  {panel}

*Problem*
When team members were manually assigned to an issue and another team is selected, the member assignments are dropped. As a consequence, any members that were assigned to the issue by the algorithm will show up in the members column, even if they don't match the assigned team. You basically have an outdated calculation result now and need to recalculate the plan to get matching member assignments.

You can, however, of course already select members of the team set that will be taken into account by the algorithm when recalculating the plan.

*Suggested solution*
Showing the outdated members has proven to be confusing for customers and we could not show calculated members unless they match the assigned team.
fields.summary: Live Plans - Do not show calculated team members in case they no longer match the selected team

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1413].
  {panel}

h5. Problem Definition
At the moment, a JIRA Portfolio user won't see the global overview whenever there are custom sprints defined, even though the sprints have the same start and end dates across all teams. 

h5. Suggestion
As long as the start and end dates of all sprints match up, JIRA Portfolio could compute the overview view, and avoid using the individual sprint names, though, as they might be different for different teams.
fields.summary: Allow custom sprints to appear on Global Overview

fields.description:
*Problem*
In case there is a calculation result available for an issue and one or more members has been assigned to it, the member column does not change when selecting another team or resetting the member assignment.

*Workaround*
Trigger a new calculation
fields.summary: Portfolio Live Plan: Member column not showing correct team members

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1411].
  {panel}

*Description:*
Actually, in Portfolio the order of epics in the hierarchical view depends on its child story ranks and do not necessarily reflects the ranks of the epics to each other.

*Suggested Solution:*
A flat list for epics and stories sorted by their rank, which would make it possible to see the actual rank of an epic and also to re-rank an epic on its own.
fields.summary: Show Epics and Stories also in a flat list
Not all shared teams listed in "Manage shared teams" page

*Workaround*
Create the team as a "Scrum" team, confirm the creation and then change the _Team Schedule_ to "Kanban".

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1407].
  {panel}

Description:
----------------
Portfolio Live Plans doesn't consider all available sprints from an agile board if the sprint belongs originally to another board.

Example:
-------------
Board A: Sprint A1
Board B : Sprint B1

Issue I1 : visible on Board A and Board B and is in scope of Sprint A1
Issue I2 : visible on Board A and Board B and is in scope of Sprint B1

When viewing Board A we will see not only Sprint A1 but also B1 because Issue I2 is visible on the board and is in scope of Sprint B1.
Same happens for Board B : Issue I1 is visible on the board and in scope of Sprint A1, therefore also A1 is visibible ins Board B.

As Portfolio Live Plans only considers sprints that directly belongs to a board (created within a board), meaning for issue I1 only sprint A1 and for issue I2 only sprint B1, the scheduling result is not as expected.
fields.summary: Portfolio Live Plans doesn't consider all available sprints from agile boards for scheduling

fields.description:
This version is specifically: 1.12.5-OD-001-D20160405T074619 in JIRA Portfolio Cloud (couldn't pick it in the Affects version list)

---

I made a Test Project with existing Epics, Stories, and Subtasks where they had assignees set.

I made a Live Portfolio with a team that contains these assignees, and sourced issues from the Test Project.

On display of the Scope tab only some items were given a Team, and Members. It doesn't seem to read the member from the Assignee field. There is also no ability to say "Calculate" for the member vs using what is the current Assignee for the Sub-Task, Story, or Epic.

Am I understanding this correctly?

Here's a screenshot that contrasts what JIRA sees:
 !Screen_Shot_2016-04-19_at_9_14_04_PM.png|thumbnail! 

And how Live Portfolio isn't reflecting it:

 !Screen_Shot_2016-04-19_at_9_14_35_PM.png|thumbnail! 

Is there a "force load data" I need to press?
fields.summary: [Portfolio Live] Teams and Members don't seem to always get read from the JIRA issue assigne

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1405].
  {panel}

*Problem*
When issues are _Done_, that is, they are assigned to a status of the done category, they should show up in Live Plans when the respective _Completion date_ filter is set. However, this filter relies on the issues having a resolution and a resolution date, because it is date-based (it shows all issues that were completed since the beginning of the active sprint / month / quarter etc.). Thus, issues that are _Done_ but don't have a resolution are not picked up by this filter.

*Suggestion* 
To address this problem, an "All" option should be added to this filter that will pick up all completed issues regardless of their resolution date.

*Workaround*
The only way to work around this for now is to adapt the work-flow and treat statuses without a resolution not as _Done_ but still as _In Progress_, otherwise these issues will never show up in Live Plans
fields.summary: Add "Show all completed issues" option to Completion date filter in Live Plans

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1404].
  {panel}

*Configuration*:
The story points field is configured for one or a list of specific projects and at the same time applicable for all available issue types.

*Result*:
The story points values set in Portfolio cannot be synced back to JIRA (e.g. via Apply updates to project/s).

*Workaround*:
Make the story points available globally (any projects) or limit it to specific issue types (not all).
fields.summary: Story points field cannot be updated to JIRA when the field is not globally available

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1403].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently you can have multiple issue sources when setting up the live plan, however certain customer would like to have a more specific rules to define certain issues only be imported via the issue sources.
h3. Suggested Solution
To have rules configuration when defining the scope from the issue sources
fields.summary: rules to define scope in the issue sources for live plan

fields.description:
Hi guys, 

I adressed this issue on the Linkedin group. Martin Suntinger asked me to post it here so you can look into it.

We are working with a pilot version of the Portfolio Live plans. We connected one of our boards to the plan and it shows a nice schedule. However, when we click the 'recalculate;' button multiple times in a row it completely rearranges the planning of the epics. Sometimes after one click, sometimes after multiple clicks. I'm sure nothing changed on the backlog between clicks that could have influenced the plan. Although some people might like this kind of undeterministic scheduling possibility, our Product Owners and stakeholders get quite unnerved by this (me too). Could you please look into this? It keeps us back from using the Live Plans because we can't trust the outcome.
fields.summary: Live plan: clicking the recalculate button mulitiple times in a row leads to changed schedules

fields.summary: Error importing new issue sources into Portfolio LABS

fields.description:
When dragging an Epic to another place on the list in Live Plans, the Epic is moved together with the Stories. But when checking in the Issues, the Epic rank has changed but does not have the correct ranking. The Stories seem to have the correct ranking.
Attached pictures show the problem.
fields.summary: Live Plans: Drag Epic (change rank) does not work properly

fields.description:
Closed issues in a JIRA project are not available in a Live Plan. Which results in not able to do progress tracking.
When the lowest issue is open (sub-Task for example) and the higher issue (Story) is Closed, then these issues are available in Live Plan and progress is shown. But when all issues are Closed, they disappear from Live Plan (version 1.12.4, 11.2.3 showed the same behavior).
fields.summary: Progress tracking in Live Plans does not work
Committing story point changes fails in certain locales

fields.description:
*Problem:*
In situations where there is no calculation result available (which, e.g., can happen after upgrading to a newer version of Portfolio) the _Themes_ report shows an info message that there is no calculated schedule available. This message provides a link for recalculating the schedule. Clicking it in the themes report will result in a bummer message.

 !missingCalculationResultInThemesReport.png|thumbnail! 

*Workaround:*
Move to either the _Scope_ table and hit the _Calculation_ button or hit _Recalculate_ in the info message shown in the schedule or the _Schedule_ report.
fields.summary: Hitting recalculate in the Themes reports view in case of missing calculation result causes an error

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1383].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently there is no wallboard view/configuration for live plan in JIRA Portfolio.

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be great to have this configuration so that customer would be able to display the latest view/updates in a graph/short summary manner of the live plan in a big/public display to let everyone be aware of it.
fields.summary: wallboard view for live plan

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1381].
  {panel}

I had previously imported issues (Epics, Stories and Tasks) from a live project into a "Sandpit" project in our Jira Cloud instance. These were given new issue names on the import so that they are completely separate from the project that they were imported from (SAN-1, SAN-2 etc).

Before trying Jira Portfolio Labs, I had previously added a new Issue Type called "Initiative" and associated it with the Sandpit project.

When subsequently trying out Jira Portfolio Labs and setting up a plan to import the issues from the Sandpit project, everything appeared to work ok and epics, stories and tasks were imported. There were, of course, no initiatives in the project at this point.

Portfolio Labs was configured to allow Initiatives in the Scope. When attempting to create new initiatives, this worked correctly. However, when trying to commit the changes back to Jira using "Review and commit changes" in Jira Portfolio Labs, the following exception occurred:

fields.summary: Exception when attempting to commit the creation of new Initiatives or Stories in Jira Portfolio Labs

fields.description:
Affects standard Portfolio Plans.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a story worth 0.5 story points
2. Import that story into Portfolio
3. Resolve that story in JIRA
4. In the plan configuration, enable "Update estimates", and set the progress metric to "Story points"
5. Run "Update from date"

Expected:
- The estimate in Portfolio should change from 0.5 to 0

Actual
- The estimate stays at 0.5

There is currently no workaround aside from setting the estimate to 0 manually.
fields.summary: Update from date does not set estimate to 0 when an item has an estimate less than 1
Dependency Mapping Tool
Allow addition of new heirarchy levels that are not associated with JIRA issue types
Allow exceptions for a team member to be handled with negative hours

fields.description:

  {panel}
